review_title: It's a great place to teach
pros: it's a college whose Mission is focussed on TEACHING, not a Research-1 place where most of the profs want to just do research.... small-ish class sizes; friendly students; teaching students to be ETHICAL citizens of the world is part of its Mission
cons: a bit too much bureaucracy, from the faculty point of view... establishes a floor, which I suppose is necessary, but also holds back the top levels of students from being able to be truly and individually innovative, Hampshire College-style. Then again, Marist College is still solvent.... and our students do a lot of amazing things in the world, so.... I guess it's not much of a con....

review_title: Marist: small school with big dreams
pros:
Marist is a fantastic community.  There is a great range of work being done here on the academic side that drives the administrative areas and in some cases the reverse is true.  Innovations and interesting new technology are common, especially with Marist's close relationship with IBM.  
The Marist community is involved in a number of charity, entertainment, and educational events; of which most staff can take advantage.  Marist folk are generally very friendly and welcoming.
Though the cafeteria had gone downhill recently, it still offers buffet-style lunch for $4.50 to employees.  The gym is available during certain hours, and there are plenty of beautiful places to walk or enjoy some quiet time.  Though the library is lacking in physical material, a number of research databases are available with full-text articles.
cons: Marist suffers from some of the same problems as other smaller schools: sometimes it is difficult to get funding for projects.  People who have worked here for a number of years often have trouble adapting to changes as the college grows and evolves into what may one day be a large university.  Old-timers (both faculty and staff) have seen the college turn from a relaxed academic institution to an aggressive academic business.

review_title: Interesting teaching experience with caveats. I've been teaching at Marist for over seven years now.
pros: Beautiful campus situated on the banks of the Hudson River with country club like setting. Many new buildings. Students mostly from advantaged upbringing. A great deal of effort and money is invested in the college's appearance.
cons: As Marist continues to grow in size much of the revenue needed to sustain this growth comes from a couple of different sources. First, the majority of the faculty, over 70%, are adjunct or contingent meaning they are poorly paid and likely to work more than one job in the greater Poughkeepsie area, in order to survive.  I question the motives of Marist administration in that its President will soon be retiring at 75% of the average of his last three years compensation. ANother way that Marist grows its revenue is by admitting freshman that are of questionable academic backgrounds, and, in more recent years, this situation seems to be getting worse as both administrators grow in both number and compensation. This is troubling. So, of the almost 3 million high school graduates in America with 27 thousand Valedictorians, 27 thousands Salutatorians, 27 thousand class presidents, it is unlikely that you will encounter students of this caliber, at Marist College.

pros: student employment is easy to balance with school schedule
cons: it can be difficult to get hours for some of the different jobs

pros: Great Benefits especially the insurance
cons: No major issues with this employer

pros: Beautiful campus and wonderful coworkers
cons: when it's busy, it is extremely busy

pros: The work you're given in any office at the College will prepare you to tackle full-time roles upon graduation. Students are generally intelligent people, as are the staff and faculty that work above you to hone in on your development. I worked in one office for 3 years of my time at Marist and I grew immensely as a student looking to become a professional down the line. My direct supervisors assisted me in getting the full-time position I have now in New York City and I had a leg up when compared to other candidates who applied for my role back when it was open for applications. To this day, I utilize skills I learned in the office at Marist and will always be grateful for the experiences I had as a student.
cons: Work-life balance is sometimes skewed, especially when you're taking a full courseload and, like I was, in the Honors Program.

pros: The job allows you to go home without bringing work with you unless it's urgent. Job security is great because of how small the teams are. Some benefits are good.
cons: Upper management is a bit of mess. They spend a lot of time helicoptering rather than helping. The work is spread across a thin amount of people who work and the compensation for it is very little. Refusal to hire anyone new because they don't match the job description word for word and starting salaries are very low now compared to when I started. technology on most of the campus is very outdated. The network has improved tenfold since I started but otherwise to make any major changes it takes years and so much time is wasted.

review_title: Beautiful Campus. Great to work there as a stepping stone. But as a career you'd need to be a professor or coach.
pros:
Incredibly gorgeous campus. High level of tech competence and availability. Most classrooms are wired for lots of multimedia. Students tend to come from affluent areas. Campus is rarely site of parties or crime, so the main campus is kept usually clean and pristine. 

The school seems to spend a considerable amount of its annual operating budget on creating new facilities or updating new facilities. Even constructing new buildings quite often. It is obvious that the money coming into the school is spent on productive endeavors and not often wasted.
cons:
Immediate surrounding areas are crime havens. Expect to commute if you are an employee as living in close proximity to the campus is a severe risk. The inner city of Poughkeepsie is a horrible area to live in or near. 

Parking is horrible. Especially during the winter. Unless you have a reserved parking spot expect to be competing with students for parking near where you need to be.

review_title: Great place to work, but poor pay
pros:
- The people are great to work with:
The director I report to is a great manager: fun, instructional, reasonable, but upper level administration can be difficult with annoying illogical policies. 

- Beautiful campus! Right on the river, what a view
cons:
- Upper level administration has illogical policies sometimes or antiquated ways of doing things

- Poor pay: is minimum wage or on the very low end of the salary range. Some professors Ive talked to report similar salaries. For a school with such endowments and a president that makes over $400k the lower level staff sure aren't getting a cut

pros: Great atmosphere, students are smart and enthusiastic. Although Poughkeepsie is not the prettiest city in New York, Marist College has a beautiful campus. It is well groomed and right on the Hudson River. There are also quite a few attractions in the surrounding area. Great colleagues; there are some really stellar people that work at Marist. Office hours for professors can be time consuming, but they are a truly great way of connecting professors with students.
cons: The cafeteria and campus food is lousy. The pay could definitely be better. There is a disconnect between departments and schools. There needs to be more communication in that area.

review_title: Proud to be a part of this community.
pros:
Its a real community, with real goals and a real cause. Theres no question in what the goals are.
Employees can take classes after 3 months (or 13 months if you are a student -> employee).
It is a beautiful place to work -- people take care of the campus.
cons:
Pay is extremely low. Raises, although frequent, do not keep pace with either cost of living nor inflation.
Many employees do not have the benefit of varied experience, and may not have enough perspective to make wise decisions.

pros: I have had several employers over my 30 year employment history and most of my experiences have been very positive.  None have been more positive than Marist College.  There is an enormous sense of community with many long tenured employees who are extremely committed to the success of the college and the student population.  It has been an extremely rewarding way to spend my last decade of employment. Beautiful campus, wonderful people, amazing benefits.
cons: Nothing negative comes to mind. Perhaps in some respects, it is difficult to advance, especially from the office clerk role.

job_title: Admissions Office Assistant in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: Working at Marist proved to be the most beneficial thing I could have done in my career! The people (in all departments across campus) are great. It really feels communal. Big pro, there are always career advancement opportunities and they look within to promote.
cons: I can't say I have a con as far as having an office job at Marist. I will say at times communication between departments can get a bit "hazy" but what do you expect from a college. And although I didn't work as a teacher I know some people who were unhappy with the teaching department.

pros: It was great to be able to work on campus while attending school. This job provided me the money to buy groceries and other college essentials.
cons: I had something like 4 managers who told me what to do. The CTO refused to allow any innovation or change. Desktop still does not have remote support, which should have been implemented years ago considering the size of the campus and the location in Fishkill.

pros: nice view, good focus on education by select departments, free education to employees and families, good health benes.
cons: low pay, no room for advancement, poor managers, union issues

review_title: Wonderful place to get an education and some part time jobs available
pros: I worked as a part time employee since I was a student, and they were very accommodating to my schedule each semester. When I was in a position that I didn't particularly enjoy, they worked with me to find something better. Everyone is a pleasure to work with because everyone loves marist and their jobs.
cons: There really are no cons, Marist is the best.

cons: I am not happy with my swing shift schedule and we do not have a locker or break room. Otherwise I have no complaints.
